metadata.title: Better Opportunities or Worse? The Demise of Cotton Harvest Labor, 1949-1964

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change in the cotton industry
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of mechanization and other factors on the displacement of cotton harvest labor, providing insights into labor displacement due to technological change.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on 12 major cotton-producing states in the United States, covering the period from 1949 to 1964.
design.geographical_focus: 12 major cotton-producing states in the United States

dependent_variables.displaced: The study estimates the causes of the decline in cotton harvest employment, focusing on mechanization and other factors.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: The study notes a decline in picking pay over the period.

key_themes: mechanization as a driver of labor displacement
text_fragments: 'I didn't stay out on that farm too long after they started usin' the cotton pickers and whatnot. That was the time we was told to leave the farm.' - Mae Bertha Carter
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a detailed account of the socioeconomic transformation in the cotton industry due to mechanization and other factors.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Post-World War II economic conditions with falling cotton prices and rising nonagricultural wages.
historical_context.institutional_context: Government farm programs, including acreage reduction and the Soil Bank program, influenced labor demand.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that mechanization and government programs were the main drivers of the decline in hand-harvested cotton labor, rather than labor supply factors like higher nonagricultural wages.
outcomes.conclusions: Labor demand factors, particularly mechanization and government policies, were the primary causes of the decline in cotton harvest labor.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that technological displacement may have improved long-term black progress by reducing the incentive for southern political interests to maintain a system of social control.
